title: 107_hr2133
content:
The Congress establishes the "Brown v. Board of Education 50th Anniversary Commission" to plan and coordinate the commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the Supreme Court decision in Oliver L. Brown et al. v. Board of Education of Topeka, Kansas et al. The Commission is tasked with planning public education activities and initiatives to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Brown decision. They will work with the Department of Education and the Brown Foundation to coordinate observances of the anniversary. The Commission for the 50th anniversary of the Brown decision shall be composed of representatives from the Department of Education, Department of Justice, and individuals appointed by the President based on recommendations from Senators. The Commission for the 50th anniversary of the Brown decision will have representatives recommended by Senators and House Members from specific states involved in the lawsuits. The Commission for the 50th anniversary of the Brown decision will have members recommended by Senators, House Members, the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, the Brown Foundation, the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund, and the Brown v. Board of Education National Historic Site. Members will serve for the life of the Commission, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission for the 50th anniversary of the Brown decision will have members recommended by various organizations. Members will serve without pay and receive travel expenses. A majority of members constitute a quorum. The Commission will hold its first meeting within 6 months of the Act's enactment and subsequent meetings as called by Co-chairperson or majority. The Commission may hire an executive director and staff as needed. The Commission for the 50th anniversary of the Brown decision will have members recommended by various organizations. The Commission will hold its first meeting within 6 months of the Act's enactment and subsequent meetings as called by Co-chairperson or majority. The Commission may hire an executive director and staff as needed. SEC. 5. POWERS. The Commission members or agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can accept gifts or donations and decide on the disposition of donated materials related to the Brown decision. The Commission, with the consent of the Brown Foundation and the Brown v. Board of Education National Historic Site, may use the United States mails for communication. SEC. 6. REPORTS.

The Commission will provide interim reports to the President and Congress by December 31 each year, detailing activities, funds, and recommendations. A final report will be submitted by December 31, 2004, accounting for all funds, expenses, and property disposition.

SEC. 7. TERMINATION. SEC. 7. TERMINATION. The Commission will terminate by February 1, 2005, and any remaining funds will be deposited in the Treasury. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $250,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2003 and 2004 to carry out the Act.
